title: Polenta
introduction: Polenta, a staple of Italian cuisine, is traditionally prepared by slowly stirring cornmeal into boiling water, demanding patience and precision. However, this foolproof method ensures a lump-free, creamy texture by initially mixing the cornmeal with cold water. This dish can be varied by using broth or milk and enriched with grated cheese.
ingredients: 1 cup coarsely ground yellow cornmeal, preferably stone-ground
instructions: 1. In a 2-quart heavy saucepan, bring 3 cups water to a boil.
2. Meanwhile, in a small bowl, whisk together the cornmeal, salt, and remaining 1 cup water.

3. Pour the mixture into the boiling water and cook, stirring, until the mixture comes to a boil. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the polenta is thick and creamy, about 30 minutes. If the polenta becomes too thick, stir in a little more water.
4. Stir in the butter. Serve immediately.
variations: Cook polenta with broth instead of water for added flavor.
Use milk in place of some of the water for a creamier texture.
Stir in grated cheese at the end of cooking for a richer taste.
